unnormalised: I'm seeing a lot of questions about charitable giving in India, so I thought I'd share some insights, especially regarding the nuances of currency and donations. People often ask what's the best way to donate and how much they should give. It's a good question!
normalised: I'm seeing a lot of questions about charitable giving in India, so I thought I'd share some insights, especially regarding the nuances of currency and donations. People often ask what's the best way to donate and how much they should give. It's a good question!

unnormalised: When donating to charities in India, it's important to understand the tax benefits under Section 80G of the Income Tax Act. For example, if you donate Rs. 5000 to a registered charitable trust, you can claim a deduction, typically 50% or 100% depending on the trust. Make sure to obtain a receipt, including the charity's registration number (e.g., Trust Reg. No. 12A/80G/2023/DEL/1234).
normalised: When donating to charities in India, it's important to understand the tax benefits under Section eighty G of the Income Tax Act. For example, if you donate rupee five thousand to a registered charitable trust, you can claim a deduction, typically fifty percent or one hundred percent depending on the trust. Make sure to obtain a receipt, including the charity's registration number (e.g., Trust R-e-g. N-o. twelve A slash eighty G slash two thousand twenty three slash D-E-L slash one thousand two hundred thirty four).

unnormalised: Another common query is about donating in foreign currency. While many international charities operate in India, it’s generally more beneficial to donate in INR. Converting USD 100 to rupees locally and donating that amount will often yield a better tax benefit and support the local economy more effectively. Also, check if the charity is FCRA compliant if it receives foreign donations.
normalised: Another common query is about donating in foreign currency. While many international charities operate in India, it's generally more beneficial to donate in I-N-R. Converting U-S-D one hundred to rupees locally and donating that amount will often yield a better tax benefit and support the local economy more effectively. Also, check if the charity is F-C-R-A compliant if it receives foreign donations.

unnormalised: Beware of fraudulent donation requests. I’ve seen people sharing QR codes and UPI IDs (e.g., donation@upi) on social media, claiming to be collecting funds for various causes. Always verify the legitimacy of the organization before donating, even if it’s a small amount like ₹100. Check their website and registration details with the Charity Commissioner.
normalised: Beware of fraudulent donation requests. I've seen people sharing Q-R codes and U-P-I I-D-s (e.g., donation at U-P-I) on social media, claiming to be collecting funds for various causes. Always verify the legitimacy of the organization before donating, even if it's a small amount like rupee one hundred. Check their website and registration details with the Charity Commissioner.

unnormalised: Finally, remember that every contribution, no matter how small, makes a difference. Whether you’re donating Rs. 50 or Rs. 5,00,000, your generosity can help improve the lives of those in need. Support causes you believe in and donate responsibly!
